article.title: Asteroseismology and Gaia: Testing Scaling Relations Using 2200 Kepler Stars with TGAS Parallaxes

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the distribution of Kepler stars in a Teff-logg diagram. What does the color of the points represent?
Figure 2a compares asteroseismic distances calculated using two different methods. What can be concluded from the overall agreement between these methods?
choices: Systematic differences between asteroseismic methods for calculating distances are significant.
The direct method for calculating distances is significantly more accurate than grid modeling.
The choice of isochrone grid has a significant impact on the calculated distances.
Systematic differences between asteroseismic methods for calculating distances are generally small.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 compares asteroseismic and TGAS parallaxes. Why is there a diagonal "edge" in the ratio plot (bottom panel) towards low parallax values?
choices: TGAS parallaxes are systematically overestimated compared to asteroseismology for distant stars.
Large TGAS uncertainties for distant stars cause them to scatter to lower values than asteroseismology.
Asteroseismic distances are systematically overestimated for low-mass stars.
TGAS systematically underestimates parallaxes for metal-poor stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 8d shows the ratio of TGAS and asteroseismic radii as a function of TGAS radius. What trend is evident in this figure?
choices: Seismic radii are overestimated for main-sequence stars and underestimated for subgiants.
Seismic radii show no significant offsets for any evolutionary stage.
Seismic radii are underestimated for main-sequence stars and overestimated for red giants.
Seismic radii are underestimated for subgiants but show no significant offset for main-sequence stars.
